title: Billionaire investor Hohn tells Canadian National to end ‘ill-advised misadventure'
text:
One thing to start: UniCredit's new boss Andrea Orcel has halved his claim for compensation from Santander over its U-turn on appointing him chief executive as his case against the Spanish bank heads to a Madrid courtroom this week.

Plus, one big collab to start: we've teamed up with our friends at Alphaville to bring you The Due Diligence x FT Alphaville Spac Master Sheet so you can check up on how your favourite (or least favourite) Spac connoisseurs are doing. Hint: as of late, for many, the answer is not well. Happy lurking.

Welcome to Due Diligence, your briefing on dealmaking, private equity and corporate finance from the Financial Times. Want to receive DD in your inbox? Sign up here. Get in touch with us anytime: Due.Diligence@ft.com.

TCI thinks Canadian National veered off course with $34bn bid

Chris Hohn isn't afraid to say what's on his mind.

The UK hedge fund billionaire behind TCI recently blasted the world's largest asset managers BlackRock and Vanguard, took on the Italian government (more on that one from DD here) and has even coached Rupert Murdoch on his dealmaking game.

Now, Hohn has inserted himself in the takeover battle pitting Canadian National against Canadian Pacific for US railway rival Kansas City Southern. TCI, which owns a 3 per cent stake in CN, has demanded that it abandons its current $34bn pursuit of the US group. (Interestingly, TCI is also the largest shareholder in CP with a 8.4 per cent stake).

And, per usual, he's got no shortage of strong opinions.

“CN already has a tremendous North American rail network; it does not need KCS to prosper in the future. It is time to end this ill-advised misadventure,” he wrote in an open letter to CN's chair Robert Pace. Read it in full here.

In short, TCI has taken issue with CN's plan to create a voting trust — a vehicle that would enable KCS shareholders to get paid before the deal receives full approval from the Surface Transportation Board, the main railway regulator.

Why? Because if the deal is later blocked by the regulator it could be forced to sell KCS at a loss. In addition, CN would also lose C$2bn in break-up fees if the deal failed to win regulatory approval.  

The way Hohn sees it, CN should drop any mention of voting trusts from its takeover bid or walk away from the deal entirely.

But for CN, the tie-up is seen as less of an “ill-advised misadventure” and more of a road to riches. Acquiring KCS would allow it to link operations from Canada to Mexico through the US at a time when cross-border trade is expected to pick up significantly.

Eurostar chugs to safety

While we're on the subject, allow DD to take you on another rail journey — this time through the English Channel, where a group of shareholders are banding together to save the Eurostar following a diplomatic dispute over who should foot the bill for a rescue package.

The Channel Tunnel train operator appeared to be steamrollering toward trouble earlier this year, as passenger numbers plunged and shareholder's pockets were wearing thin.

But there is hope. Eurostar has secured a £250m bailout from shareholders including France's state-owned railway group and 55 per cent shareholder SNCF, Canadian institutional fund manager Caisse de dépôt et placement du Québec, Hermes Infrastructure and the Belgian state rail operator.

It's no coincidence that the UK is missing from the list. Transport secretary Grant Shapps said in February that Eurostar was “not our company to rescue” given it was majority owned by the French state.

As it turns out, the French newspaper Le Figaro may have been wrong when it declared the train “the end of British insularity” when it first opened in 1994.

As vaccines roll out and business travellers venture back into a post-Brexit world, that theory will be tested once again.

The sprint to become south-east Asia's everything-app

The stakes in south-east Asia's great “super app” rivalry just got higher.

An $18bn alliance between Indonesian start-ups Gojek and Tokopedia has spawned a ride-hailing, ecommerce, delivery and payments behemoth to rival Singapore's SoftBank-backed Grab.

Like its largest competitor, the new company — coined GoTo — is on a mad dash to the public markets before the hype cools down, writes the FT's Mercedes Ruehl in a dispatch from Singapore.

Executives are targeting a dual listing in New York and Jakarta by the end of the year, with a public market valuation of up to $40bn. And the sooner the better — the company is burning through cash as it competes with Grab, south-east Asia's most valuable start-up.

The rival tech group plans to join the Nasdaq through a $40bn Spac deal later this year, making it the largest merger between a private business and a Spac to date if all goes as planned.

*Note: this chart was created before Gojek Tokopedia agreed to their merger

Meanwhile, the two face a well-financed foe, the Shopee-owned, Nasdaq-listed Sea group, which is increasingly expanding its turf across financial services and food delivery. It's now a more than $100bn company thanks to its fast-rising share price.

There's big money on the line. SoftBank, Tencent, Alibaba, Facebook, Google, Warburg Pincus, KKR, PayPal and Visa are among the players with skin in the game. 

Some, like SoftBank and Tencent, have bet on more than one horse.

And it's off to the races.

Job moves

  • Gordon Smith, a top lieutenant of JPMorgan Chase boss Jamie Dimon, is to step down from his role at the end of the year. Veteran bankers Marianne Lake and Jennifer Piepszak, both considered potential successors to Dimon, will replace him as co-heads of its consumer banking unit. More here.

  • UBS has promoted Jason Hutchings to Emea head of private financing markets, a role he will carry out in addition to his position as head of the bank's Emea natural resources group. 

  • Anas Biad has joined Sequoia Capital as a partner in its London office. He was previously at Silver Lake. 

  • Finsbury Glover Hering has hired Daniel Schäfer, Bloomberg's German bureau chief, as a partner on its capital markets team.

  • Freshfields has hired Adam Golden as a partner and head of US life sciences transactions for the firm in New York. He was previously head of Hogan Lovells' US corporate practice.
